original_data.question:
A 40-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a checkup. She has felt weaker lately and has lost some weight. She denies any urinary issues. Her BUN at her last visit 4 months ago was 45 mg/dL, and her creatinine was 2.0 mg/dL. Her laboratory studies this visit are seen below:

Hemoglobin: 8 g/dL
Hematocrit: 29%
Leukocyte count: 9,500/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 197,000/mm^3

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 5.9 mEq/L
HCO3-: 17 mEq/L
BUN: 59 mg/dL
Glucose: 99 mg/dL
Creatinine: 2.3 mg/dL
Ca2+: 9.0 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

model_response: {'A': 'Acute kidney failure', 'B': 'Chronic kidney failure', 'C': 'Obstructive uropathy', 'D': 'Renal cell carcinoma'}[?]The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) with a BUN of 45 mg/dL and creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL on her last visit. Her laboratory studies show a BUN of 59 mg/dL and creatinine of 2.3 mg/dL, indicating a progression of her CKD. Her electrolytes are within normal limits, and her glucose is slightly elevated. Her hematologic studies show a low hemoglobin and hematocrit, indicating anemia. Her leukocyte count is elevated, indicating infection. Her platelet count is elevated, indicating a possible malignancy. Her calcium level is low, indicating hypocalcemia. Her creatinine level is elevated, indicating acute kidney failure superimposed on her chronic kidney disease. Her electrolytes are within normal limits, indicating that she does not have metabolic acidosis. Her glucose level is normal, indicating that she does not have diabetic ketoacidosis. Her BUN level is elevated, indicating that she has prerenal azotemia. Her creatinine level is elevated, indicating that she has acute kidney failure. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that her kidneys are not filtering properly. Her elevated BUN level indicates that her kidneys are not reabsorbing properly. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that her glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is decreased. Her elevated BUN level indicates that her GFR is decreased. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that her GFR is decreased. Her elevated BUN level indicates that she has a decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that she has a decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated BUN level indicates that she has decreased renal perfusion. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that she has decreased renal perfusion. Her elevated BUN level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated BUN level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated BUN level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated BUN level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated BUN level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated BUN level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated BUN level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated BUN level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated BUN level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated creatinine level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. Her elevated BUN level indicates that she has decreased effective circulating volume. question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Providers of initial care for patients. These PHYSICIANS refer patients when appropriate for secondary or specialist care.
Checkup is a general examination or inspection, especially one carried out by a doctor or dentist.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
An abnormality of the composition of urine or the levels of its components. [HPO:probinson]

The urea concentration of the blood stated in terms of nitrogen content. Serum (plasma) urea nitrogen is approximately 12% higher than blood urea nitrogen concentration because of the greater protein content of red blood cells. Increases in blood or serum urea nitrogen are referred to as azotemia and may have prerenal, renal, or postrenal causes. (From Saunders Dictionary & Encyclopedia of Laboratory Medicine and Technology, 1984)
The act of going to see some person or place or thing; it can cover a short or long period but refers to a non-permanent arrangement.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
The breakdown product of creatine, a constituent of muscle tissue, that is excreted by the kidney and whose serum level is used to evaluate kidney function.
The act of going to see some person or place or thing; it can cover a short or long period but refers to a non-permanent arrangement.
An extract of Goa powder; a complex mixture of reduction products of chrysophanic acid, emodin, and emodin monomethyl ether; used locally in ringworm, psoriasis, and eczema.

The volume of packed RED BLOOD CELLS in a blood specimen. The volume is measured by centrifugation in a tube with graduated markings, or with automated blood cell counters. It is an indicator of erythrocyte status in disease. For example, ANEMIA shows a low value; POLYCYTHEMIA, a high value.
The clear portion of BLOOD that is left after BLOOD COAGULATION to remove BLOOD CELLS and clotting proteins.
chief cation of the extracellular body fluids.
atom of potassium having a positive charge; potassium is the chief cation of muscle and most other cells (intracellular fluid).

Electroneutral chloride bicarbonate exchangers that allow the exchange of BICARBONATE IONS exchange for CHLORIDE IONS across the cellular membrane. The action of specific antiporters in this class serve important functions such as allowing the efficient exchange of bicarbonate across red blood cell membranes as they passage through capillaries and the reabsorption of bicarbonate ions by the kidney.

The urea concentration of the blood stated in terms of nitrogen content. Serum (plasma) urea nitrogen is approximately 12% higher than blood urea nitrogen concentration because of the greater protein content of red blood cells. Increases in blood or serum urea nitrogen are referred to as azotemia and may have prerenal, renal, or postrenal causes. (From Saunders Dictionary & Encyclopedia of Laboratory Medicine and Technology, 1984)
The breakdown product of creatine, a constituent of muscle tissue, that is excreted by the kidney and whose serum level is used to evaluate kidney function.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
